intro: Parrya cheiranthoides, commonly known as the Sierra Valley cress, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other mustard plants. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and streambanks. It produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in clusters. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and have a slightly hairy texture, contributing to its distinctive botanical appearance.
